newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan to allow foreign banks to issue samurais-MOF.
newsitem.headline: Japan to allow foreign banks to issue samurais-MOF.

text.p: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will allow foreign commercial banks to issue samurai bonds, effective April 1, a ministry official said on Monday.
Samurai bonds are yen-denominated bonds issued in Japan by non-resident institutions and by foreign governments.
Foreign commercial banks had been banned from issuing yen-denominated bonds in Japan partly because of a regulation restricting the number of Japanese banks that can issue yen bonds at home.

Lifting the ban on foreign commercial banks' samurai bond issues is part of government efforts to deregulate Japan's financial markets and is also in response to requests from foreign countries and banks, the ministry official said.

He added that effective from April 1, the ministry will also allow Japanese banks to procure longer-term euroyen funds with a period of more than one year as a step to liberalise fund-raising by domestic banks. --Tokyo treasury desk 81-3-3432-1396
